medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The pain came on suddenly around midnight prior to admission while he was sleeping. It was located in the epigastrium and was at its worst. The patient had somewhat similar abdominal pain during a previous ruptured peptic ulcer, but in a different location. He also experienced nausea and vomiting starting the night before admission. Emesis was described as bilious and non-bloody. He last kept down oral intake the afternoon before admission. There was no diarrhea or constipation, and no fever or blood in stool.
medical_history.past_medical_history: History of perforated peptic ulcer over 10 years ago (H. pylori positive); left hip dislocation and subsequent avascular necrosis of the left hip, for which he underwent a left hip replacement; bone-on-bone severe degenerative arthritis of the right hip; two ankle fractures and a left calcaneal fracture that healed with fixation or casting; diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis, intermittently positive RF, trial of plaquenil did not improve symptoms.
medical_history.social_history: The patient has been drinking more heavily for the past 6 weeks due to his mother's illness and issues with his girlfriend, currently consuming alcohol both beer and vodka at an unspecified rate. He states he has never experienced withdrawal from alcohol or seizures in the past. His last drink was the night prior to admission.
